content: The "Fair Benefits for Seniors Act of 2000" repeals the 1993 increase in tax on Social Security benefits. The "Fair Benefits for Seniors Act of 2000" repeals the 1993 increase in tax on Social Security benefits. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changes to the taxation of social security and tier 1 railroad retirement benefits, with certain provisions no longer applying after December 31, 2000. Conforming amendments adjust the percentage of taxable income and modify specific sections of the Social Security Amendments of 1983. The amendments made by the "Fair Benefits for Seniors Act of 2000" include changes to the taxation of Social Security benefits, with specific paragraphs being amended and effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2000. Improvement of Consumer Price Index for the Elderly by Congressionally Appointed Review Committee. The Consumer Price Index Review Committee, composed of 15 members appointed by Senate and House leadership, includes 11 experts in economics and 4 representatives of individuals aged 65. Members serve for the duration of their appointment. The Consumer Price Index Review Committee, consisting of 15 members appointed by Senate and House leadership, includes 11 economics experts and 4 representatives of individuals aged 65. Vacancies on the Committee are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and individuals chosen to fill vacancies serve for the duration of the Committee. The Committee must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and a majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Consumer Price Index Review Committee consists of 15 members appointed by Senate and House leadership, with a majority needed for a quorum. The Committee selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members. The Committee's duties include studying and improving the method for determining the "Consumer Price Index for the Elderly." The Consumer Price Index Review Committee is tasked with studying and improving the method for determining the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly, ensuring accuracy in measuring changes in expenditures for retirees in the United States receiving old-age and survivors insurance benefits. The study includes developing an implementation plan and creating an accurate market basket of goods and services for the Elderly Consumer Price Index. The Consumer Expenditure Survey will be redesigned and expanded to collect expenditure patterns representative of the total retiree population in the United States receiving old-age and survivors insurance benefits. The areas and outlets priced by the Bureau of Labor Statistics for the Experimental Consumer Price Index for the Elderly will be modified to reflect a representative collection of typical purchases by retirees. The Committee will modify the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly to accurately reflect the total retiree population, including pricing items and removing limitations. Additionally, they will study how to determine an accurate consumer price index for individuals receiving disability benefits. The Committee will submit a report to Congress on the study conducted regarding the consumer price index for individuals receiving disability benefits. They have the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence to carry out their purposes. The Committee has the authority to obtain information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. They can request data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics and operate like other government departments. The Committee can accept gifts or donations of services or property. Members who are not federal government officers or employees will be compensated at a daily rate equal to the annual rate of basic pay for level III of the Executive Schedule. Members who are federal officers or employees will serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided for Committee members. The Chairperson of the Committee has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws and regulations. Compensation for the executive director and staff can be determined by the Chairperson without regard to specific provisions. The Committee can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The rate of pay for personnel should not exceed level IV of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Committee without additional reimbursement. The Chairperson can procure temporary services as needed. The Committee can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws, with pay not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. Temporary services can be procured by the Chairperson at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Committee will terminate one year after its initial meeting, and necessary funds are authorized for its operations. The Bureau of Labor Statistics will establish a pilot program to test the accuracy of the "Consumer Price Index for the Elderly" to reflect changes in expenses typical for retirees receiving Social Security benefits. The program will run from the report submission under section 3(b)(2) until December 2003. Additionally, an interim application of the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers will be in effect. SEC. 5. INTERIM APPLICATION OF CONSUMER PRICE INDEX FOR ALL URBAN CONSUMERS. The Commissioner of Social Security will use the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers for cost-of-living adjustments until the Official Consumer Price Index for the Elderly is implemented. SEC. 6. APPLICATION OF CONSUMER PRICE INDEX FOR THE ELDERLY. The Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics will prepare and publish the Official Consumer Price Index for the Elderly based on the recommendations in the report submitted by the Consumer Price Index Review Committee, unless a joint resolution disapproving the report is enacted. The Consumer Price Index Review Committee must submit a report within 90 days, excluding certain days when Congress is not in session. A joint resolution without a preamble must be introduced within that period for congressional consideration. The Consumer Price Index Review Committee must submit a report within 90 days for congressional consideration. Congress disapproves the report regarding the implementation of the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly. The resolution introduced in the House of Representatives goes to the Committee on Ways and Means, while in the Senate, it goes to the Committee on Finance. If a committee fails to report the resolution within 60 days after the Consumer Price Index Review Committee's report, the committee is discharged from further consideration, and the resolution is placed on the appropriate calendar. The resolution shall be considered in the same manner as a resolution under the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 after being reported by the committee. Cost-of-living computation quarters will be based on the Social Security Act starting from January 1 of the following calendar year. The Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics will use the Official Consumer Price Index for the Elderly to calculate cost-of-living adjustments for old-age and survivors insurance benefits under the Social Security Act for retirees aged 62 and older. Appropriations are authorized for the Bureau of Labor Statistics to carry out this section.
